title: Live Updates: Israeli Troops Push Into Gaza City, Forcing Desperate Palestinians to Flee
content: Hundreds of thousands of people remained in the city with hardly anywhere to go. Israel said the ground operation, after nearly two years of war, was needed to keep Hamas militants from regrouping.

title: He Fled Putin’s War. The U.S. Deported Him to a Russian Jail.
content: Antiwar Russians are being sent back as part of President Trump’s immigration crackdown, despite facing imprisonment and other dangers.

title: Trump Leaves Tense America Behind for Royal Retreat on U.K. State Visit
content: President Trump’s trip to Britain will involve horse-drawn carriages and a stay in an ancient castle. For British officials, the visit may feel less like a fairy tale.

title: Denmark’s Parenting Test Becomes the Latest Flashpoint in Greenland
content: The case of a young Greenlandic woman who was ruled incapable of keeping her baby has become the latest flashpoint with Denmark.

title: President Trump’s State Visit to the UK: What to Know
content: The president and the first lady will be hosted by King Charles III and Queen Camilla at Windsor Castle. Mr. Trump will also travel to the prime minister’s country residence, Chequers.

title: For the First Time in 215 Years, a Woman Leads Mexico’s Cry of Independence
content: Claudia Sheinbaum, the country’s president, was the first woman to give the country’s annual Grito de Dolores, a tradition dating to a priest’s call to arms against Spain more than two centuries ago.

title: Rubio Says ‘Time Is Running Out’ for Gaza Deal
content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio spoke about Gaza ahead of a short Tuesday visit to Qatar, which is angry over an Israeli strike against Hamas leaders on its territory.

title: Russia Indoctrinates Children From Occupied Ukraine at 210 Sites, Study Says
content: War crime investigators at Yale discovered a program of re-education and military and police training that was larger than estimated earlier.

title: Israel Is Committing Genocide in Gaza, U.N. Inquiry Says
content: In earlier reports, the commission found that Israel had committed war crimes and crimes against humanity in its conflict with Hamas, but stopped short of calling it genocide. Israel denounced the accusation as “fake.”

title: Starvation and Bombs in Besieged Sudanese City As Residents Cry for Help
content: At least 260,000 civilians trapped in El Fasher face a dire choice: risk being starved or bombed if they stay, and raped or killed if they flee.

title: The Fleeting Fantasy of a King Who Would Return to Save Nepal
content: Fury at the country’s politicians had led earlier this year to a failed royalist uprising, which may have been an unheeded warning of the popular discontent that exploded on the streets this month.

title: ‘Squid Game’ Star Lee Jung-jae Talks About Korean Fan Culture
content: Lee Jung-jae, who has been a star in South Korea for decades, said social media has made audiences more zealous. He thinks he knows how to keep them happy.

title: Trump’s Tariffs Test Mark Carney’s Leadership in Canada
content: After a stunning election victory on an anti-Trump message, Prime Minister Mark Carney is adjusting to the realities of dealing with the United States. Critics call it capitulation.

title: India-Pakistan Tensions Hit New Pitch With Cricket Snub
content: The Indian players refused to shake hands with their Pakistani opponents at the first meeting of the sides since the two countries exchanged hostilities this year.

title: Where will people in Gaza City go?
content: There are few places for people in Gaza City to flee to, even as Israel launches its ground offensive.

title: It Isn’t Just the U.S. The Whole World Has Soured on Climate Politics.
content: How do we think about the climate future, now that the era marked by the Paris Agreement has so utterly disappeared?

title: Panic Grips Gaza City as Israel Launches New Ground Operation
content: “I scream all the time,” said one Palestinian living in the city in northern Gaza. Others said they felt terrified as tanks and ground troops rolled in.

title: Israel’s Ground Offensive in Gaza City Capped Months of Strikes and Threats
content: In the coming days, additional troops are expected to gradually advance into the city.

title: New Research Helps Explain Gas Craters in Siberia
content: Spontaneous gas explosions appear to be increasing in northern Russia because of climate change and some specific local conditions.

title: Here’s the latest.
Israel Launches Gaza City Ground Offensive, Officials Say
content: The long-planned take over of the city began early Tuesday, according to officials, despite hundreds of thousands of people still sheltering there.

title: Federal Judge Declines to Intervene for Migrants Deported to Ghana
content: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan said her hands were “tied” with regard to the migrants, even though they held protective orders, in another victory for President Trump’s deportation campaign.

title: Trump World’s Deals With the U.A.E.
content: We dug deeper into lucrative transactions involving the Trump family’s cryptocurrency firm and the United Arab Emirates.

title: Trump World’s Deals With the U.A.E.
content: We dug deeper into lucrative transactions involving the Trump family’s cryptocurrency firm and the United Arab Emirates.

title: Venezuela’s President Maduro Denounces U.S. Boat Attack, as Trump Announces Another
content: The Venezuela leader, Nicolás Maduro, said that the Trump administration was trying to start a war in the Caribbean.

title: Young People Suing Trump Over Climate Have Their Day in Federal Court
content: They claim Trump’s executive orders are unconstitutional. The government says their lawsuit should be thrown out. The two sides are set to clash this week in Montana.

title: Surprising Guests at Belarus-Russia War Games: Two American Observers
content: The invitation by Belarus came as its autocratic leader has been trying to improve relations with the Trump administration, which has been receptive.

title: How an Emirati Royal Won the Battle for A.I. Chips
content: Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan of the United Arab Emirates secured a tentative A.I. chip deal with the United States. His company also struck a $2 billion deal with President Trump’s crypto start-up. David Yaffe-Bellany, a technology reporter for The New York Times, walks us through both deals’ intersecting timelines.

title: In Giant Deals, U.A.E. Got Chips, and Trump Team Got Crypto Riches
content: A lucrative transaction involving the Trump family’s cryptocurrency firm and an agreement giving the Emiratis access to A.I. chips were connected in ways that have not been previously reported.

title: A Times Investigation Into Trump, UAE and 2 Giant Deals: 5 Takeaways
content: A $2 billion crypto deal and an agreement to sell valuable chips to the United Arab Emirates were intertwined in ways that have not been previously reported.

title: Suspect in Madeleine McCann Disappearance Refuses Interview With UK Police
content: Christian Brückner, the main suspect in the 2007 case, rejected an interview request ahead of his release this week from a German prison for a separate crime, the British police said.

title: Angered by Israel’s Attack in Qatar, Arab Leaders Meet to Weigh Response
content: Some Arab officials are pushing for tangible, but not military, action against Israel, and Egypt’s president said the Israeli strike threatened diplomatic ties that Israel spent years cultivating.

title: U.S. and China Reach ‘Framework’ for a TikTok Sale
content: Top economic officials met in Madrid for a second day, with deadlines looming on tariffs and a ban on TikTok in the United States if it is not sold by its Chinese owner, ByteDance.

title: G.O.P. Plan on Pesticides Faces Revolt From MAHA Moms
content: The provision in the government funding bill could shield pesticide companies from billions of dollars in lawsuits.

title: What Malnutrition Has Done to Gaza’s Children
content: Even children who recover will carry the physical consequences for the rest of their lives.

title: Turning Against Vaccines, America Is a Global Outlier
content: Most governments are trying to fight vaccine hesitancy with science and investment, while the United States heads in the opposite direction.

title: Nonprofit Gets Two Paintings Stolen by Nazis Pulled From Auction
content: The paintings were among more than 300 works seized during World War II from Adolphe Schloss, a German Jew who lived in France and amassed a collection of old master paintings.

title: Protests Against an Israeli Cycling Team Shut Down a Major Race
content: The final day of the three-week long Vuelta a España came to a premature end as pro-Palestinian protesters blocked streets.

title: Trump’s State Visit Will be Biggest UK Security Operation Since Coronation
content: The fatal shooting of Charlie Kirk has intensified consideration about potential threats, experts said. British authorities had already made extensive security plans.

title: What Malnutrition Has Done to Gaza’s Children
content: The enclave is experiencing some of the highest levels of malnutrition since the fighting began. Even children who recover will carry the physical consequences for the rest of their lives.

title: Pope Leo Says He Cannot Broker a Peace Deal for Ukraine
content: Pope Leo XIV said that while popes can be advocates for peace, it was less “realistic” for them to serve as mediators.

title: ​Kim Seongmin, Defector Who Pierced North Korea by Radio, Dies at 63
content: As a military propagandist, he fled the North by jumping off a train. In the South, he broadcast forbidden outside news to isolated North Koreans.

title: After Fiery Protests, Nepal’s Leader Promises a Brief, Caretaker Term
content: Prime Minister Sushila Karki, a former chief justice, said she had accepted her new role reluctantly. Major political parties say the process is unconstitutional.

title: Ricky Hatton, British Boxer and Former World Champion, Is Dead
content: The British authorities said that the boxer, who retired in 2012, was found unresponsive at a home in Greater Manchester.

title: Arab Ministers Meet on Response to Israeli Attack in Qatar
content: Arab foreign ministers gathered on Sunday in the Qatari capital, Doha, to lay the groundwork for a summit there the next day.

title: U.S. and China Resume Talks on Tariffs and TikTok
content: Economic officials meeting in Madrid are seeking to head off a November tariff deadline.

title: What to Know About Malawi’s Presidential Election
content: The decision by the country’s top court to overturn the last presidential race was hailed as a victory for democracy. But there are fears corruption will taint the vote on Tuesday.

title: Russia Made Drone Production a Supreme Priority. Now It Swarms the Skies.
content: Ukraine is struggling to defend itself against the growing number of attack drones that Moscow has started using in its onslaughts.

title: How the Trump Administration Is Dismantling America’s Cancer-Research System
content: Here are the takeaways from The New York Times Times Magazine article on how the cancer-research system, which has helped save millions of lives, is under threat in one of its most productive moments.

title: After Bolsonaro’s Conviction, Brazil Already Considers His Amnesty
content: Brazil’s top court sentenced former President Jair Bolsonaro to 27 years in prison. The nation’s Congress is already debating how to free him.
